metadata.titleEn: Integrated environment observation data of base camp in Hulugou sub-basin of Heihe River Basin (2013)
metadata.description:
1. Data overview
The data set of the base camp integrated environmental observation system is a set of ENVIS (IMKO, Germany) which was installed at the base camp observation point by qilian station.It is stored automatically by ENVIS data mining system.
2. Data content
This data set is the daily scale data from January 1, 2013 to December 31, 2013.Including air temperature 1.5m, humidity 1.5m, air temperature 2.5m, humidity 2.5m, soil moisture 0cm, precipitation, wind speed 1.5m, wind speed 2.5m, wind direction 1.5m, geothermal flux 5cm, total radiation, surface temperature, ground temperature 20cm, ground temperature 40cm, ground temperature 60cm, ground temperature 80cm, ground temperature 120cm, ground temperature 160cm, CO2, air pressure.
3. Space and time scope
Geographical coordinates: longitude: 99° 53’e;Latitude: 38°16 'N;Height: 2980.2 m
metadata.instructions: Data file name: hulugou basin 2013 base camp integrated environmental observation system data set.xlsx; it can be viewed and edited by WPS or excel and other software.

background: Understanding cryospheric hydrology and the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff is critical for sustainable water management especially in arid inland river basins such as those in northwest China where water resources mainly come from alpine areas. The Earth’s cryosphere is facing rapid changes in the duration, extent, and mass of snow and ice, which have had multiple impacts on the environment across a range of temporal and spatial scales. Changes in mountain snow, glaciers, and permafrost have resulted in significant downstream impacts in terms of the quantity, seasonality, and quality of water. This shrinkage has modified the water cycle and river discharge in cold regions and caused the rise of global mean sea level. Serving as a solid reservoir for many endorheic and exorheic basins, the mountain cryosphere is the regulator of major rivers and provides most of the water resources in arid regions in China and its neighboring countries. However, because of inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions, the significance of the impacts of cryospheric changes and the severity of their consequences remain unclear in China.
research objective: The scientific objective of the CHOICE is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions. Four key science questions have been identified: The spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation need to be determined. The effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow need to be determined. The effects of changes in the vegetation pattern in the vertical landscape zones on water balance and river runoff in the mountains must be assessed. A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas.
challenges: Understanding such changes in these vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges because of their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.
methods: Each AWS features the long-term monitoring of the following meteorological variables: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature (LST), soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. We also conducted long-term standard meteorological field (SMF) manual observations for reference to those obtained at AWS. The total discharge has been monitored by a continuously stream-gauging station at the catchment outlet since 2009. From 2009 to 2012, we also manually used the float protocol and a stopwatch to estimate the nonfreezing period discharge in a meadow subcatchment and a moraine–talus subcatchment. To apply hydrological models in the alpine catchment, we have obtained long-term continuous soil parameter data in the soil pit synchronously with those collected at AWS. An SI-111 infrared radiometer (Apogee Instr. Inc.) was used to measure the LST. During the early stage of the CHOICE, evapotranspiration was measured with two manual weighing microlysimeters, which were 40 cm in depth and 31.5 cm in diameter and were installed in the SMF at the Hulu-1 field on 1 July 2009 with an electronic scale of 2 g (0.026 mm) in precision. With the development of the CHOICE, five automatic microlysimeters (CHOICE-LYS40, T&D) were arranged in the same field as the AWS of the Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 field in August 2013. An EC150 system (Campbell Scientific Inc.) was installed on a lattice mast at 5.8 m at the Hulu-2 field in September 2011. Four cluster wells were installed in 2011 and 2014 for groundwater monitoring and sampling. On fixed-point scale, six SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors (Campbell Scientific Inc.) measure snow depth synchronously with AWS. In this system, three thermistor cables were installed that crossed the riverbed–water, water–ice, and ice–air interfaces. We conduct the work of precipitation intercomparisons by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauge. Precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment were performed with six total rain-weighing sensors (TRwS204, MPS System Ltd) with a single alter shield and synchronized with AWS. Fourteen LST observation sites with similar elevations but different aspects and slopes were built around the Hulu-3 field. Two LST observation sites were built to analyze the influences of plants on LST. To study the runoff process of canopy precipitation to surface runoff in different landscapes, two runoff fields (shrubs and meadows) (15 by 3 m) were established at a shrub-encroached alpine meadow hillslope in September 2010. Four methods were used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in the Hulu-1 field including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer (Hood IL-2700, Germany), and the ring cutter method. Groundwater samples used for isotope analysis were collected from 12 wells between 2014 and 2016, and stream water samples were collected from 12 sites that were approximately evenly distributed from upstream to downstream between 2011 and 2016. A Picarro GasScouter G4301 gas concentration analyzer with a re-entry control system and six respiration chambers installed on the permafrost zone of the Hulu catchment in August 2017. The observation period of canopy precipitation interception began in June 2010. A total of four sap flow sensors (CAF, ECOMATIK) were installed to estimate transpiration. Variations in the diversity of the soil microbial community under meadow, shrub, marshy meadow, and moraine–talus were observed along an elevation gradient in the Hulu catchment in July 2013. An AWS was erected at the top of the glacier (4817 m asl) in September 2015; the site is not affected by the surrounding mountains. To obtain reliable turbulent data, EC system measurements were made adjacent to the AWS at a height of 4 m beginning in October 2017. To harvest the water contained in fog, five identical standard fog collectors were installed at Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 in July 2014. A warming simulation experiment was begun in September 2016. Two flight campaigns were performed in the Hulu catchment.
findings: In recent years, a series of studies have been published using the CHOICE sharing platform data, and a number of researchers have used the CHOICE data for studies of alpine meteorology, cryospheric hydrology, groundwater, soils, and isotopes. According to the six AWS of the CHOICE obtained throughout the Hulu catchment and peripheral precipitation data from five China Meteorological Administration stations (Zhangye, Minle, Sunan, Qilian, and Yeniugou), two or more yearly EMPs exist in the northern Qilian Mountains. A diminished accumulation zone will result in a reduction in the transport and expansion of the glaciers, and then the glaciers will have to retreat to limit themselves to reduce ablation. Based on 10-yr observations in the western cold regions of China, especially those obtained in the Upper Hei River basin (UHR), a new CBHM was created to evaluate the effects of cryospheric changes on stream flow from the UHR. In the past 50 yr, river runoff has generally shown an increasing trend as a result of increased rainfall, snowfall, and glacial runoff in the cold regions of western China.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in understanding cryospheric changes in remote alpine regions?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge is the remoteness and sparse observations in these regions, which result in significant biases and errors in precipitation measurements. This makes it difficult to accurately assess the impacts of cryospheric changes on water resources.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific meteorological features monitored in a mountainous environment observation system?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, precipitation amount

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the environmental data collected by an automated weather station in alpine regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, wind direction, radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, precipitation amount

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'ENVIS综合环境观测系统' in the context of environmental data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of environmental data collection, 'ENVIS综合环境观测系统' refers to a comprehensive environmental observation system that automates the storage of various meteorological and environmental data, including air temperature, humidity, soil moisture, precipitation, wind speed and direction, and more.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques for long-term meteorological variables in alpine regions compare with those used for measuring land surface temperature (LST) in the same areas?
Comparison.Answer: Both methods involve long-term monitoring, but meteorological variables are captured using AWS and manual observations, while LST is specifically measured using an SI-111 infrared radiometer. LST observation sites are strategically built to analyze influences of elevation and landscape features, offering a targeted approach compared to the broader meteorological measurements.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection strategy for snow depth using Sonic Ranging Sensors compare with the methods applied for soil moisture and temperature measurements in alpine environments?
Comparison.Answer: Snow depth is measured using SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors, synchronized with AWS for continuous snow monitoring. Soil moisture and temperature are tracked using multiple instruments at different depths, offering detailed vertical profiles. Snow depth monitoring is a singular focused measurement, while soil data collection provides comprehensive subsurface insights, reflecting the varied complexity in measuring different environmental factors.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges faced in measuring cryospheric variables, and how do these challenges affect data interpretation?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges include the remoteness of regions, sparse observations, and biases in precipitation measurements. These issues can lead to inaccuracies in understanding the impacts of cryospheric changes on hydrological processes and water resources.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in understanding changes in vulnerable regions with sparse observations, and how do these affect data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges arise due to the remoteness and sparse observations in vulnerable regions. Precipitation observations, for example, are often beset with significant biases and errors, which complicates the data collection methods and affects the accuracy and reliability of gathered data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors have contributed to the need for comprehensive observation data in understanding the hydrological processes and impacts of cryospheric changes in mountainous regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inadequate observation data and a lack of knowledge about cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales have contributed to the need for comprehensive observation data. Understanding cryospheric changes and their impacts on water resources requires detailed environmental data to assess variations in water quantity, seasonality, and quality, driven by changes in mountain snow, glaciers, and permafrost.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of diverse data collection methods, such as AWS, EC systems, and sap flow sensors, influence the understanding of hydrological processes in alpine regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of various data collection methods can provide a more comprehensive understanding of hydrological processes by capturing diverse environmental variables, leading to better evaluation and modeling of the effects of climate and cryospheric changes on mountain hydrology and water resources.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind collecting comprehensive observation data about environmental factors in mountainous regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives are to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address challenges such as biases and errors in precipitation observations in remote and sparse regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because understanding changes in these vulnerable regions is critical, and significant biases and errors in precipitation observations can hinder accurate assessments of environmental and hydrological processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of conducting long-term monitoring of meteorological variables using automatic weather stations (AWS) in the context of hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to provide reliable and comprehensive data on various meteorological variables to support the application of hydrological models in alpine catchments and to advance the understanding of environmental and cryospheric changes affecting water resources.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed for measuring soil hydraulic properties like infiltration and conductivity in mountainous regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In mountainous regions, soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity are measured using various methodologies, including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer, and the ring cutter method. These methods provide a range of approaches to obtain accurate soil parameter data essential for hydrological modeling.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to capture and analyze land surface temperature (LST) variations across different slopes and aspects in the Hulu catchment?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To capture LST variations, fourteen observation sites were established around the Hulu-3 field with similar elevations but different aspects and slopes. An SI-111 infrared radiometer is utilized to measure the LST, while additional sites analyze the influence of vegetation on LST, providing a comprehensive understanding of temperature distribution in varying topographies.

Enablement.Question: What methods have enabled the collection of comprehensive observation data about environmental factors in mountainous regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of automatic weather stations (AWS) for long-term monitoring and manual standard meteorological field observations have enabled the collection of comprehensive environmental data. Additional methods include the use of microlysimeters for evapotranspiration measurements, EC150 systems for gas concentration analysis, and various sensors for snow depth and soil moisture monitoring.

Enablement.Question: How have technological advancements facilitated the monitoring of cryospheric changes and hydrological processes in remote alpine areas?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements like automatic microlysimeters, EC systems for turbulence data, and Sonic Ranging Sensors have facilitated the monitoring of cryospheric changes. These tools, along with long-term soil parameter data collection and the installation of AWS, have enabled detailed studies of hydrological processes in remote alpine areas.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do current data collection methods address the challenges of sparse observations in high-altitude, remote regions?
Enablement.Answer: Current data collection methods such as the installation of AWS at various elevations, the use of infrared radiometers for land surface temperature, and stream-gauging stations for discharge monitoring help address the challenges of sparse observations. These methods provide continuous and synchronized data collection across different environmental conditions and locations.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential reasons for expected discrepancies in precipitation measurements across different methods and instruments in alpine environments?
Expectation.Answer: Discrepancies in precipitation measurements may arise due to biases and errors inherent in different instruments, such as pit gauges, DFIR gauges, and rain-weighing sensors. Variability in environmental conditions like wind and topography can also affect accuracy, requiring intercomparison experiments to assess and improve measurement methods.

Expectation.Question: Why might the establishment of diverse observation sites for parameters like soil moisture and snow depth be crucial for developing a suitable distributed hydrological model in alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: Diverse observation sites enable the collection of data across varying elevations, aspects, and slopes, which is essential for capturing the complex interplay of factors affecting hydrology in mountainous terrains. This diversity is key to refining models that account for cryospheric, meteorological, and hydrological dynamics in these regions.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the methods being used to monitor cryospheric changes in capturing accurate environmental data in remote alpine regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The methods are comprehensive, featuring long-term monitoring of various meteorological variables including air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, and others. However, the effectiveness is challenged by the remoteness of regions and sparse observations, which can lead to significant biases and errors, particularly in precipitation observations.

Judgmental.Question: What is the level of reliability of the data collection techniques used for understanding cryospheric hydrology in mountainous regions, considering the challenges posed by sparse observations?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection techniques, which include the use of AWS for continuous monitoring and various other advanced instruments and methodologies, are quite reliable. Yet, the sparse observations in these challenging terrains can affect the reliability, requiring careful validation and intercomparison to ensure accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: To what extent does the existing data collection approach facilitate the development of accurate hydrological models in alpine catchments?
Judgmental.Answer: The existing data collection approach is extensive and includes diverse methodologies such as long-term soil parameter data collection, meteorological monitoring, and specialized measurements like LST and evapotranspiration. These efforts are crucial for developing accurate hydrological models, although challenges in data accuracy due to regional remoteness must be addressed.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods in remote and alpine regions can effectively capture accurate precipitation data given the challenges in these areas.
Assertion.Answer: In remote and alpine regions, precipitation observations face significant biases and errors. To address these challenges, various methods are employed, such as using six total rain-weighing sensors synchronized with automatic weather stations (AWS) and conducting intercomparisons with pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference gauge.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how researchers tackle the lack of observational data in alpine regions to assess cryospheric changes and their impacts effectively.
Assertion.Answer: Researchers tackle the lack of observational data by deploying multiple stations and sensors across various locations, including automatic weather stations (AWS), microlysimeters for evapotranspiration, snow depth sensors, and groundwater monitoring wells. These are synchronized across the study area to provide a more complete understanding of cryospheric changes and their impacts.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the data collection techniques used for monitoring cryospheric changes and hydrological processes in alpine regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The field utilizes various long-term monitoring methods, such as Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) for meteorological variables, including air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and direction. The field also employs manual and automated systems for measuring evapotranspiration, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation. Stream-gauging stations monitor total discharge, while soil parameter data are collected synchronously with AWS data. Advanced instruments like infrared radiometers, microlysimeters, and gas concentration analyzers are used for specific measurements. Groundwater and stream water samples are collected for isotope analysis, and fog collectors are utilized to capture water from fog.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in data collection for understanding the hydrological impacts of cryospheric changes in remote alpine catchments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in data collection include the remoteness and sparse observational coverage of alpine regions, which complicate the acquisition of comprehensive data. Precipitation measurements are particularly prone to biases and errors. The deployment of instruments like AWS, manual field observations, and automated systems requires careful planning and maintenance to ensure data quality and reliability. Additionally, the complexity of cryospheric processes and their interactions with hydrology present significant analytical challenges.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets related to cryospheric hydrology and environmental monitoring in alpine regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies for expanding or refining datasets include enhancing the spatial and temporal resolution of observations by deploying additional AWS and specialized sensors across diverse landscape zones. Implementing advanced remote sensing technologies and integrating them with ground-based observations can provide more comprehensive coverage. Collaborative efforts to share data among research institutions can enrich existing datasets. Furthermore, developing and applying improved hydrological models that incorporate cryospheric dynamics can refine datasets and enhance the understanding of cryospheric impacts on hydrology.
